At one point when I tried to an Eclipse within Eclipse after a restart,
I discovered a seriously truncated plug-in list (just 6 plug-ins, possibly
those referenced from the installed feature).

Any clues as to how to debug this?

Possibly relevant/irrelevant. At one point I had most Eclipse plug-ins imported
and after I migrated Eclipse releases, Eclipse persistently failed during
start up until I removed an OSGI plug-in.

I now get very bad feeling for any stack trace with osgi in!

This could be cause by problems described in bug 74624.
If you can update to a newer 3.1 build (like M4), please do so, otherwise 
please attach a reproduceable test case. thanks.

Created an attachment (id=17349)
Zipped update site to demonstrate bug on Eclipse 3.1M4 (and 3.0)

Reproducible case as requested

Vanilla Eclipse 3.1M4
Help->Software Updates->Find and Install... 
Search for new features
New Local site for unzipped attachment
 ... there is only the one feature to install ...

... NullPointerException after final Install click.

Edward,

The problem is the missing id and version attributese on the <plugin> element 
in the plugin.xml.
If you add the id and version then things should work fine. Note that during 
install update does not parse the plugin for validation.

Thanks for the diagnosis. But that leaves at least 2 problems.

a) Why does PDE "Create manifest" remove the id if it is needed?

b) Why doesn't the NullPointerException diagnose at least the file name
that was being parsed during the crash, and preferably the line context too.

logging problem fixed.Also made the version 0.0.0 when not there.
With the latest build I could not set the plugin version to nothing, when 
using the PDE editor.
If you see a problem with the plugin editor, please open a bug on PDE UI.

Just to be clear, can someone confirm that the <plugin> does NOT require an id, 
version or any other attribute.  If there is a manifest.mf then there are no 
relevant attributes on the <plugin> tag.  No errors, warnings or other output 
should result.
*** Bug 83554 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Let me clarify my comment #3: there was no manifest.mf in that plugin.
Just a plugin.xml without id and version, and some other files, but certainly 
no manifest.

In that case, then after the creation of the manifest.mf, the build.properties 
was not updated to include the META-INF folder in the binary build section.

if you use PDE to create a manifest.mf would it be reasonable to have PDE add 
the required entry line to build.properties or add a marker saying that there 
is a manifest.mf (or plugin.xml for that matter) but it is not listed in the 
build.properties?  Seems like this would catch some troublesome error cases.  
In generall people onthe news group seem to have trouble moving from "things 
working in the workspace" to "deployed things working"...

In general, we (PDE) would like to stay away from the business of implicitly 
maintaining the build.properties file, as it is only the user himself who 
knows what he wants packaged, and he is therefore responsible for maintaining 
it.  That is why we explicitly tell you on the overview page of the editor 
that prior to exporting, you should visit the Build page and ensure you 
checked everything that you want included.

However, in this case, the idea to automatically add the manifest.mf file to 
the list of bin.includes when PDE generates the manifest certainly seems 
appealing.

I sympathize (and agree) with avoiding magic edits.  It may just be enough to 
extend the notion of plugin validation to include the idea that if the project 
has a manifest.mf and/or plugin.xml the user very likely wants them included in 
the bin output and so should have bin.includes entries.

The bummer here is that they may have an Ant filepattern/fileset (e.g, *.xml, 
META*/**, ...) which covers the files.  PDE likely does not want to get into 
that ;-)

So, perhaps simply adding it is the right option.  Chances are that at the time 
of conversion they do not have something that covers META-INF/MANIFEST.MF so 
its a pretty reasonable thing to simply add.

Allow me to confirm. The problems were caused by omitting the manifest from a
manifested plug-in.

a) without plug-in attributes: diagnosed very violently as a 
NullPointerException during installation update.

b) with plug-in attributes: diagnosed very obscurely as a plug-in load failure
in the config but not PDE error log.

These were certainly caused by a foolish user not understanding the PDE 
interface for manifests and builds.

May I therefore add my two-pennyworth to the magic edit debate.

The PDE Build page has two modes Custom/Standard. Change it to 4-way.

Custom as now.
Customised pretty much as not-custom at present.
Standardised warning about deviations from standard policies.
Standard enforcing standard policies.

For standard policies, many alternatives should be grayed out.
So plugin.xml is supposed to be in binary build.
MANIFEST.MF if present is supposed to be in binary build.
about.html if present is supposed to be in binary build.
.project is supposed to be in source build.
.classpath is supposed to be in no build.
.cvsignore if present is supposed to be in source build.

etc.

Perhaps the not-present files could be pale-greyed to indicate what
could be present and where they are supposed to be.
